dt: {bc}of, relating to, or being an eon of geologic history that comprises the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic or the corresponding systems of rocks {dx}see {dxt|Geologic Time Table|geologic time|table}{/dx}

et: Greek {it}phanerós{/it} "visible, conspicuous" (from {it}phan-,{/it} base of {it}phaínomai, phaínesthai{/it} "to become visible, come to light, appear" + {it}-eros,{/it} adjective suffix) + {et_link|-o-|-o-} + {et_link|-zoic:2|-zoic:2} {ma}{mat|fantasy:1|}{/ma}

The term was introduced by the American geologist George Halcott Chadwick (1876-1953) in "Subdivision of Geologic Time," {it}Bulletin of the Geological Society of America,{/it} vol. 41 (1930), pp. 47-48. The name refers to the easily visible fossil records that appear in this eon, in contrast to the earlier period, which Chadwick referred to collectively as the Cryptozoic (see {et_link|crypto-|crypt-}, {et_link|-zoic:2|-zoic:2}).
shortdef: of, relating to, or being an eon of geologic history that comprises the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic or the corresponding systems of rocks
